qas.question: What school of thought serves as a model for canon theory?
Which philosopher is quoted by the Catechism?
What word is not specifically given meaning in the Code of the Church?
What does Aquinas define as the aim toward which law is working?
What term expresses the idea of law derived from Aquinas as interpreted by the Catechism?
What generally follows the principles of Aristotle and Plato?
What term is explicitly defined in the code?
What does Aquinas say is working towards the good of the church?

context: <b5_0>Canonical jurisprudential theory<b5_0/> generally follows the principles of <a0_0>Aristotelian-Thomistic<a0_0/> legal philosophy. While the term "<a2_0><b7_0>law<b7_0/><a2_0/>" is never explicitly defined in the Code, the Catechism of the Catholic Church cites <a1_0><b6_0>Aquinas<b6_0/><a1_0/> in defining law as "...<b8_0>an ordinance of reason<b8_0/> for <a3_0>the common good<a3_0/>, promulgated by the one who is in charge of the community" and reformulates it as "...<a4_0>a rule of conduct<a4_0/> enacted by competent authority for the sake of the common good."
